citeinfo.origin: Department of Commerce (DOC), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), NOAA Coastal Services Center, Landscape Characterization and Restoration Program
Florida Department of Environmental Protection, Apalachicola National Estuarine Research Reserve
citeinfo.title: Sediment grab data from October 1999 in Apalachicola Bay, Florida

pubinfo.publish: NOAA's Ocean Service, NOAA Coastal Services Center (CSC)

descript.abstract: The Apalachicola Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve and the NOAA Coastal Services Center worked together to map benthic habitats within Apalachicola Bay, Florida. The bay and the lower portions of four distributaries were surveyed on 11-22 October 1999 using three benthic sampling techniques. This data set represents the sediment grain size and organic content information gathered from grab sampling. Grabs were collected at 136 stations throughout the bay.
descript.purpose: Grain size and percent organic content were measured from the sediment grab samples. These data were collected to support RoxAnn acoustic data interpretation and sediment profile imagery analysis throughout the Apalachicola Bay system.

idinfo.useconst: It is the responsibility of the user to determine the appropriate use of the data product.

cntinfo.cntpos: Landscape Characterization and Restoration Program Manager
cntinfo.hours: 9 am to 5 pm, Eastern Standard Time

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.0 (Build 2195) Service Pack 4; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.3.0.800

attracc.attraccr: Values were checked against hard copy data sheets provided by the analysis laboratory. Total organic carbon analyses were repeated for samples where two subsamples differed by more than 10% (e.g., if sediment TOC was 1%, the replicate subsample must have a TOC between 0.9% and 1.1%).

dataqual.logic: All data are believed to be logically consistent.
dataqual.complete: All grab data were not included in this data layer. Percent values of sand, silt, clay, gravel, and total organic content, as well as a Folk description of grain size and median grain size (in phi units) are included. Other calculated grain size metrics (such as mean grain size and percent skewness) were not included, but these data can be found in the Apalachicola Bay benthic database, available from the NOAA Coastal Services Center.

horizpa.horizpar: Stations were located in the field using a differential Global Positioning System (GPS), and station coordinates, date and time of day were recorded upon arrival at each station.

vertacc.vertaccr: Not relevant to the data set.

citeinfo.origin: Apalachicola Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve
citeinfo.title: Apalachicola Bay Sediment Survey, October 1999
citeinfo.othercit: Tierra Consulting conducted the grain size analysis. The Reserve conducted the organic content analysis.

srcinfo.srccontr: Textural analysis and organic content for sediment grabs collected in Apalachicola Bay, Florida.

procstep.procdesc: Grab samples were collected using a 0.04 square meter Shipek grab. Sediment grain size distributions (mean and median grain size, % size class) and total organic content (%) were measured in the laboratory from the sediment grabs. For grain size distribution, each sample was washed with deionized water, dried, and weighed. The coarse fraction was separated from the fine fraction (sand/silt) by sieving through U.S. Standard Sieve Mesh No. 230 (62.5 m). Sediment texture of the coarse fractions was determined at half-phi intervals by passing the sediment through nested sieves on a Ro-Tap apparatus. The weight of the material collected on each sieve was recorded. A Sedigraph 5,000 ET Particle Size Analyzer was used to analyze the fine fraction (< 62.5 m). Sediment texture descriptions followed the Wentworth classification as described in Folk (1974). Organic content was measured using a weight-loss-upon-ignition procedure. A longitudinal section comprising approximately one third of the sample volume was sliced from each frozen sample for analysis. These sections were dried in a 60 degrees Celsius oven for 2 to 3 days. Sections were then weighed and burned for 2 hours at 550 to 600 degrees Celsius in a muffle furnace. Sections were then cooled in a dessicator and weighed. Organic content was assumed to be the weight lost upon ignition and expressed as a percentage.
procstep.srcused: Folk, R.L. 1974. Petrology of Sedimentary Rocks. Austin, Texas.
